title-group.article-title: Eye tracking for the classification of visual function in individuals with vision impairment: A validation in Para athletes

abstract.p: Eye tracking has the potential to be used as a meaningful measure of the consequences of vision impairment (VI), yet a comprehensive test battery is lacking. In this study, we sought to evaluate the feasibility and validity of a test battery of eye movements as a tool to measure visual performance in individuals with VI. A test battery including fixation stability, smooth pursuit, saccades, free viewing, and visual search was administered to 46 athletes with VI and 10 control participants. Feasibility was determined by test completion rates. Construct validity was assessed by comparing eye movement outcomes across different VI subgroups, and predictive validity was evaluated by examining the relationship between eye movement metrics and in-competition sport performance. The test battery proved feasible, with 88% of athletes with VI able to complete the tests. Eye movement variables distinguished between subgroups, supporting construct validity. For example, participants with combined central and peripheral vision loss showed longer fixation durations during free viewing and visual search, while those with central vision loss had prolonged saccades during free viewing and fewer and smaller eye movements during visual search. Predictive validity was indicated by significant correlations between eye movement metrics and sport performance, suggesting that eye tracking can predict real-world outcomes. Our findings suggest that an assessment of eye movements provides a feasible, valid, and largely objective measure of the functional consequences of VI that may extend beyond what information is obtained using traditional tests of visual acuity and visual field and that those measures can help to predict the sport performance of Para athletes.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The accurate assessment of visual function is fundamental to the diagnosis of vision impairment (VI) and for understanding the functional consequences of that impairment on activities of daily living. Visual function refers to the measurable physiological abilities of the visual system (Colenbrander, 2005), such as visual acuity (VA) and visual fields (VF), which are used to determine the visual capabilities of individuals with and without VI. However, these traditional measures were developed for medical, diagnostic purposes and may not capture how well individuals with and without VI use their vision in real-world settings. Alternatively, an individual's functional vision (Colenbrander, 2005) reflects the ability to perform visually guided tasks in everyday life, such as those encountered in reading (Calabrèse, Bernard, Faure, Hoffart, & Castet, 2014; Kabanarou & Rubin, 2006; Murata, Miyamoto, Togano, & Fukuchi, 2017), driving (Bronstad, Albu, Bowers, Goldstein, & Peli, 2015; Kübler et al., n.d.), and in sports (Land & McLeod, 2000; Mann, Spratford, & Abernethy, 2013). Ideally, tests of visual function predict an individual's functional vision in some way, though this might not always be the case.

Eye movements are an important aspect of visual function but have been traditionally measured by clinicians observing and grading the quality of the eye movements in a very subjective manner. Recent advances in eye-tracking technology offer new opportunities for measuring eye movements in a more precise and objective way (Gestefeld, Marsman, & Cornelissen, 2021; Grillini, Ombelet, Soans, & Cornelissen, 2018). Unlike subjective assessments that rely on verbal responses or patient cooperation, eye tracking can directly measure oculomotor behavior, including fixational, smooth pursuit, and saccadic eye movements (Nieboer, Ghiani, De Vries, Brenner, & Mann, 2023). These eye movements are essential components of visual function, and impairments in these abilities (e.g., through nystagmus or strabismus) have the potential to significantly impact activities of daily living (Kelly, Cheng-Patel, Jost, Wang, & Birch, 2019; Perrin Fievez, Lions, & Bucci, 2018). However, the degree to which impairments to eye movements impact these activities—independent of the effects of VA and VF—remains insufficiently understood.

It is becoming increasingly common to use eye tracking to evaluate the eye movements of people with VI (Nieboer et al., 2023). Nieboer et al. (2023) previously reviewed the literature to determine the degree to which eye tracking can be used to assess visual function in the presence of VI. The included studies reported considerable success when testing individuals with VI, yielding usable data from 96.5% of participants (Nieboer et al., 2023). The high success rate highlights the potential that eye tracking offers as a tool for assessing visual function in those with impairment; however, it might also reflect the selectiveness of the ocular conditions examined in those studies as researchers might have deliberately avoided studying ocular conditions that they might have expected to have made eye tracking difficult, for instance, in individuals with nystagmus, strabismus, or abnormal anterior segments. Hence, further investigation is needed to determine the applicability of eye tracking in a wider range of ocular conditions.

The systematic review by Nieboer et al. (2023) also revealed a set of five common tests of eye movements that have been used in individuals with VI: (a) fixation stability, (b) smooth pursuit, (c) saccades, (d) free viewing, and (e) visual search. A test of fixation stability assesses the ability of an individual to maintain steady gaze on a specific point. A test of smooth pursuits evaluates the smoothness and accuracy of eye movements when tracking a moving target. A test of saccades measures the speed and accuracy of rapid eye movements between different fixation points. Free viewing involves observing and exploring visual stimuli without specific instructions, offering insights into spontaneous visual exploration behavior. Lastly, visual search tasks assess the efficiency of locating specific targets within a visual field, providing information on visual attention and search strategies. These tests have been proposed to collectively provide a comprehensive assessment of various aspects of visual capabilities in individuals with vision impairment.

The aim of this study was to evaluate an eye-tracking test battery for assessing the visual capabilities of individuals with VI. We could find no existing test available that was suitable for persons with (profound) vision impairment. Therefore, we developed a battery of tests of eye movements, based on the framework outlined in Nieboer et al. (2023), that assessed fixation stability, smooth pursuit, saccades, free viewing, and visual search. The test battery was employed to assess the eye movements of Paralympic athletes with vision impairment. The feasibility of the test battery was evaluated by seeking to establish what proportion of individuals with VI could successfully complete the test. To establish the validity of the test battery, we focused on two main types of validity: construct validity and predictive validity. Construct validity refers to the extent to which a test accurately measures the theoretical construct it is intended to assess (e.g., visual function) and should be sensitive to variation between individuals with different types and severities of impairment (Harris, Bird, Smart, Wilson, & Vine, 2020). We hypothesized that the test battery would differentiate between healthy controls and participants with VI, as well as between those with central and peripheral vision loss. For example, we expected that participants with peripheral vision loss would show reduced performance on saccadic and visual search tests, while participants with central vision loss would perform worse on fixation stability and smooth pursuit tests.

We then assessed predictive validity, which reflects how well the test can predict an outcome external to the test itself (Harris et al., 2020), such as reading or sport performance. Predictive validity is a subtype of criterion validity and is closely related to construct validity because, if a test measures the construct well, it should also be able to predict related real-world outcomes (Strauss & Smith, 2009). There is convincing evidence that skilled athletes use distinct eye movement strategies compared with less-skilled athletes (i.e., different functional vision), for instance, use of the “quiet eye” in targeting tasks (Harle & Vickers, 2001; Vine, Moore, & Wilson, 2011), more predictive strategies in hitting (Mann et al., 2013; Sarpeshkar, Abernethy, & Mann, 2017), and more structured forms of search in complex team sports (Mann, Causer, Nakamoto, & Runswick, 2019; Vaeyens, Lenoir, Williams, Mazyn, & Philippaers, 2007). But the evidence is much less clear as to whether better athletes have better visual function, that is, a better capacity to perform, for instance, more accurate or faster eye movements (for some evidence, see studies in fast ball sports [Liu, Burris, & Appelbaum, 2020] and in complex team sports [Morgan & Patterson, 2009]). In athletes with vision impairment, it seems reasonable to expect that reduced visual function will, at some point, impact sport performance, even in less visually demanding sports such as judo (Krabben, Mann, et al., 2021; Krabben, Mashkovskiy, Ravensbergen, & Mann, 2021; Krabben, Ravensbergen, et al., 2021; Krabben, Ravensbergen, Nakamoto, & Mann, 2019; Krabben et al., 2022; Krabben, van der Kamp, & Mann, 2018), swimming (Fortin-Guichard, Ravensbergen, Krabben, Allen, & Mann, 2022), and track athletics (Zenk, Willmott, Fortin-Guichard, Mann, & Allen, 2025; Zenk, Willmott, Mann, & Allen, 2024). Little is known though about how eye movements might relate to sports performance in athletes with VI. Given that eye movement deficits are often present in VI, we hypothesized that athletes with greater impairments, as measured by the eye-tracking battery, would exhibit poorer sport performance. Our choice to test the relationship in two sports which would be considered less visually demanding (i.e., swimming and track athletics) also provides a robust test of the predictive validity of the test battery.

By establishing both construct and predictive validity, we sought to demonstrate the effectiveness of the eye-tracking battery as a tool for assessing the functional consequences of VI. In our case, we sought to establish predictive validity in Para athletes as a group of young individuals who are well adjusted to their impairment, but we clearly see the potential for the tool to predict the functional ability of all persons with vision impairment. Ultimately, we hope that the results will improve the way functional vision is assessed in the presence of VI and the way that impact on real-world activities is understood.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p:
A total of 56 participants took part in the study: 46 athletes with vision impairment (15 females; age = 25.3 ± 6.7 years) and a control group of 10 healthy young adults (7 females; age = 21.7 ± 4.6 years) who volunteered during Para sport events. The athletes were recruited through Para sport events (Para Track Athletics and Para Swimming) organized for athletes with a vision impairment. Athletes with vision impairment have reduced or no vision that is caused by damage to the eye structure, optical nerves or optical pathways, or visual cortex of the brain (International Paralympic Committee, n.d.). The minimum impairment criteria for athletes with vision impairment to compete in Para sport events is a visual acuity of 1.0 logarithm of the minimum angle of resolution (logMAR) or worse, or a visual field restricted to 40 degrees in diameter or less. There were no specific exclusion criteria for our study based on the type of ocular condition, but athletes with a visual acuity worse than 2.60 logMAR in their better eye—those in sport class B1—were excluded from the study because their vision was likely to be too poor to discriminate any stimulus presented to them on a screen. Sport class represents the grouping of athletes based on how their impairment impacts their sport performance, aiming to minimize the influence of impairment on competition outcomes (International Paralympic Committee, n.d.). Athletes with vision impairment are typically grouped into three classes (International Paralympic Committee, n.d.): –
B3 athletes have a VA between 1.0 and 1.4 logMAR (inclusive), or a VF restricted to 10 to 40 degrees in diameter (best eye, best correction).–
B2 athletes have a VA between 1.5 and 2.6 logMAR (inclusive), or a VF restricted to less than 10 degrees in diameter (best eye, best correction).–
B1 athletes have a VA poorer than 2.6 logMAR (best eye, best correction).

Comprehensive medical diagnoses, including visual acuity and visual field measures, were obtained for the athletes using data collected by ophthalmologists or optometrists affiliated with the International Paralympic Committee (IPC). This information was accessed through the Sport Data Management System of the International Paralympic Committee. The sample of participants included individuals with various causes of vision impairment, such as Stargardt disease, retinitis pigmentosa, high myopia, optic atrophy, congenital cataract, and amblyopia, among others. Additional details regarding participant characteristics can be found in Supplementary Table S1. To help with the categorization of the conditions, we manually classified the type of each participant's impairment based on their medical documentation. An optometrist and a vision scientist independently labeled each participant as having healthy vision, central vision loss, peripheral vision loss, or combined central and peripheral vision loss. We additionally annotated those with nystagmus or strabismus. Cohen's kappa was calculated to measure interrater reliability, and cases of disagreement were discussed between the two raters until consensus was reached on the most appropriate categorization for that individual.

The study was approved by the Scientific and Ethical Review Board of the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam and was conducted in accordance with the tenets of the Declaration of Helsinki with the informed consent of all participants.

sec.title: Apparatus and materials
sec.p: The eye movement data were collected using a Pupil Invisible head-mounted infrared eye-tracker (Pupil Labs GmbH, Berlin, Germany). The eye tracker recorded the eye movements of both eyes of participants at a sampling rate of 200 Hz. This eye-tracking system employs an artificial intelligence–based algorithm that circumvents the explicit detection of two-dimensional features and instead performs gaze estimation by directly regressing gaze estimates from concurrent eye images (Tonsen, Baumann, & Dierkes, 2020), eliminating the need for any manual calibration, which can be specifically challenging for individuals with vision impairment (Nieboer et al., 2023). The reported spatial accuracy of the Pupil Invisible is 4.6 degrees uncalibrated (Tonsen et al., 2020). We conducted a verification process to check the accuracy of the automated calibration. A grid of five circles, each with a diameter of approximately 14 degrees, was presented on a screen to the participants. Participants were instructed to direct their central vision (or preferred retinal locus if central vision was not available) toward each circle in the grid one by one. Any calibration offset observed during this verification process was manually corrected using the Pupil Invisible software. For participants with VI, tracking accuracy may be affected by factors such as eccentric fixation, nystagmus, or strabismus. Given that individuals with central vision loss often use preferred retinal loci, gaze recordings may not always correspond to intended fixation points.

The visual stimuli for the experiment were presented on an Acer Nitro xv273xb monitor, which had a screen size of 27 inches and a resolution of 1,920 × 1,080 pixels. The monitor had a high refresh rate of 240 Hz, ensuring smooth and precise presentation of stimuli. The stimuli were presented using a custom-built tool developed in PsychoPy (Version 2021.2.3).

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: During the experiment, participants wore the head-mounted eye tracker and sat 60 cm from the monitor (subtending a visual angle of 55.3 degrees and 34.7 degrees in width and height, respectively). All tests and eye movement recordings were conducted binocularly. Participants were instructed to minimize their head movements, but their head was not restricted in any way.

The test battery consisted of five different tests of eye movements, all of which were to be attempted by all participants. These paradigms, designed based on the systematic review by Nieboer et al. (2023), included tests of (a) fixation stability, (b) smooth pursuit, (c) saccades, (d) free viewing, and (e) visual search. The tests were also administered in this order. Participants were given short breaks between each test to rest. The total duration of all tests combined, including breaks, was approximately 30 minutes.

sec.title: Fixation stability
sec.p: The test of fixation stability assessed the ability to maintain steady fixation on a target (Bellmann, Feely, Crossland, Kabanarou, & Rubin, 2004; Crossland, Sims, Galbraith, & Rubin, 2004; Ghasia et al., 2018; Murray et al., 2022; Tarita-Nistor et al., 2017). The fixation target was a white cross consisting of a single horizontal and vertical line (thickness = 1 degree of visual angle) that spanned the full width and height of the screen, respectively, and, within the white cross, an inner black cross with lines of 0.4 degrees visual angle. The background was black. The design of the target allowed participants to locate and direct their gaze toward the center of the cross, even in the presence of a central scotoma. Participants were instructed to maintain steady fixation on the center of the cross until it disappeared. The cross was presented for 30 seconds. Participants were instructed to limit their head movements and minimize blinking during the task. The initial 2 seconds of the test were excluded from analysis in case participants were still locating the center of the cross during that period.

Stability was measured using the bivariate contour ellipse area (BCEA). The BCEA quantifies the spread of fixation points by calculating the area of an ellipse that encompasses fixation points for a given proportion of all eye positions during the test. A lower BCEA indicates greater fixation stability. The BCEA was computed using Equation 1, where σh represents the standard deviation of gaze coordinates in the x direction, σv represents the standard deviation of gaze coordinates in the y direction, ρ represents the product-moment correlation of these two position components, and k is a constant (set at 1.14) representing the chosen probability area of 68% of eye positions during a trial (Crossland et al., 2004). The other outcome variable for fixation stability was the number of saccades, which are labeled as intrusive saccades since they are unwanted during a period of steady fixation and can be a consequence of vision impairment.

sec.title: Smooth pursuit
sec.p: We employed a step-ramp paradigm to test smooth pursuit eye movements (González, Tarita-Nistor, Mandelcorn, Mandelcorn, & Steinbach, 2018; Natela, Shanidze, & Velisar, 2020; Raashid, Liu, Blakeman, Goltz, & Wong, 2016; Shanidze, Heinen, & Verghese, 2017). Initially, a white fixation dot (diameter 1 degree) was presented at the center of the screen, against a black background, for a duration of 1.5 seconds if the target were to move vertically over the screen or 2 seconds if the target were to move horizontally. The difference in delay ensured that each trial had the same total duration since horizontal targets were presented for 0.5 seconds longer. Subsequently, the fixation dot disappeared, and a target dot with a diameter of 1 degree appeared at a location 6 degrees away from the fixation point, at 0, 90, 180, or 270 degrees. After a delay of 0.5 seconds, the target dot began to move in the direction of the center of the screen with a constant velocity of 10 degrees per second. If the target moved vertically, its duration was set to 1.25 seconds, while for horizontally moving targets, the duration was 1.75 seconds to optimally use the size of the screen in both directions (Natela et al., 2020). Following the specified duration, the target dot vanished, and the fixation dot reappeared, marking the start of a new trial.

During the test, each target location was presented five times, in a random order, resulting in a total of 20 trials. Participants were instructed to shift their gaze from the fixation dot to the target dot and to track the target dot when it started moving.

Smooth pursuit performance was assessed by calculating the gain, which in this case represents the ratio of eye velocity during target pursuit to the velocity of the target. A gain of 1.0 indicates perfect average pursuit. Smooth pursuit gain was calculated across the entire trial, including both the open-loop and closed-loop phases. The open-loop phase was difficult to define, particularly for participants with nystagmus, whose eye movements lack a stable period. Trials were not excluded based on target interception, as some participants may have relied on nonfoveal retinal locations that were not accounted for in the eye-tracking calibration. Gain variability within individual trials was not analyzed; instead, saccade detection was used as an indirect measure of smooth pursuit consistency. The number of saccades, which typically occur as catch-up saccades when the eye's velocity is insufficient to track the target, was counted, and the amplitudes of these saccades were determined.

sec.title: Saccades
sec.p: A step paradigm was used to assess saccades (Fayel et al., 2014; Giacomelli et al., 2021; Niechwiej-Szwedo, Chandrakumar, Goltz, & Wong, 2012). The paradigm began with a white fixation dot (diameter 1 degree) initially displayed at the center of the screen against a black background. The dot remained visible for 1.5 seconds before it disappeared and immediately reappeared as a target dot at a specific location away from the center of the screen, remained visible for 2 seconds, and then disappeared again. The dot then immediately reappeared at the center of the screen as a fixation dot, marking the beginning of a new trial. There were 16 possible locations for the target dot to appear away from the center of the screen, positioned either 6 or 10 degrees away from the center in one of eight directions from the fixation dot (i.e., at 0, 45, 90, 135, 180, 225, 270, and 315 degrees).

During the test, each target location was presented twice in a random order, resulting in a total of 32 trials. Participants were instructed to shift their gaze from the fixation dot to the target dot when it appeared and vice versa.

From the saccade paradigm, the number of saccades per trial was extracted. While one saccade per trial is expected in a healthy population, multiple saccades per trial suggest difficulties in locating peripheral targets (e.g., peripheral vision loss). Additional variables extracted from the saccade data included peak velocity, saccadic reaction time (the time delay between target onset and saccade onset), and saccadic gain. Saccadic gain was calculated by dividing the amplitude of the primary saccade by the amplitude of the target step (Raashid, Wong, Chandrakumar, Blakeman, & Goltz, 2013). A gain above 1.0 indicates overshoot, while a gain below 1.0 indicates undershoot of the saccade(s).

sec.title: Free viewing
sec.p: The free-viewing paradigm was divided into two parts (Asfaw, Jones, Mönter, Smith, & Crabb, 2018; Gameiro et al., 2018; Gestefeld et al., 2021; Smith, Glen, & Crabb, 2012). In the first part, participants were presented with a series of 30 photos, each displayed for a duration of 3 seconds. The photos encompassed a diverse range of themes, including scenes from nature landscapes, cityscapes, and sports events. The photos varied in composition, with some featuring cluttered scenes and others focusing on central objects or individuals. Most of the photos were in full color (n = 27), while the remainder were black and white. Each photo occupied the entire screen, with dimensions of 1,920 by 1,080 pixels. The selection of photos ensured a wide range of saliency across different regions of the screen, capturing participants’ attention and prompting exploratory eye movements.

In the second part, participants watched a single video of planes taxiing, preparing for take-off, and stationary planes, while various vehicles, such as fueling cars, moved between the planes at different speeds. The video content was highly dynamic, featuring objects appearing on the screen from various directions. The dynamic nature of the video was designed to elicit reactionary and tracking eye movements. The video lasted 52 seconds and was displayed in full screen.
Participants were instructed to simply watch the photos and videos without any specific task or response required from them. All participants viewed the same photos and video.

From the paradigm, the following eye movement measures were extracted per trial: average number of fixations, average duration of fixations, average number of saccades, average duration of saccades, amplitude of the largest saccade, and average amplitude of saccades. The scan path, which quantifies the exploration of the scene, was calculated by summing the amplitudes of all saccades. The scan path provides insight into how efficiently a participant explores a visual scene. In individuals with vision impairment, scan paths can become longer, more fragmented, or more constrained—depending on the nature of the impairment—reflecting compensatory or less efficient eye movement strategies (Asfaw et al., 2018; Gestefeld et al., 2021; Pambakian et al., 2000; Smith, Crabb, Glen, Burton, & Garway-Heath, 2012). Additionally, we calculated the BCEA (Equation 1), in this case, representing the area of the screen explored by the participants (Smith, Glen, et al., 2012).

sec.title: Visual search
sec.p: An existing test of visual search was adopted, specifically designed for individuals with vision impairment (Fortin-Guichard et al., 2022; Krabben, Ravensbergen, et al., 2021). The test assesses the ability to identify the presence of a circle among a grid of squares. The visual search test comprised three levels of difficulty. In the easiest level, participants were presented with a 3-by-3 grid of white shapes on a black background. Each shape subtended an angle of 8.3 degrees of visual angle (equivalent to 2.0 logMAR). In the second level, an 8-by-8 grid was used, with shapes subtending an angle of 2.6 degrees of visual angle (equivalent to 1.5 logMAR). The third and most challenging level consisted of a 15-by-15 grid, with shapes subtending an angle of 0.83 degrees of visual angle (equivalent to 1.0 logMAR).

During each trial, the stimuli were presented for a maximum of 30 seconds. Participants were required to respond whether a circle was present or not as quickly as possible by pressing the left or right key on a keyboard, respectively. Prior to the full test, participants completed six familiarization trials using the easiest test level, where the circle was present four times.

The full test consisted of 18 trials for each level of difficulty, with the circle being present in 12 of the 18 trials. The order of the trials within each level of difficulty was randomized between participants. For data analysis, the most difficult level completed by each participant was used. A level was considered completed if the response accuracy was above chance level (7 out of 12 correctly identified circles, and 3 out of 6 correctly identified the absence of circles). Measures of performance were the number of correct answers and average response time on the most difficult level completed. Additionally, eye movements during the search were extracted; these included average number of fixations per second, average duration of fixations, average number of saccades per second, average duration of saccades, amplitude of the largest saccade, average amplitude of saccades, and scan path in degrees per second.
For all 40 dependent variables, the average over all trials (if applicable) was used for further data analysis. For an overview of the used variables, see Table 1.

sec.title: Eye movement analyses
sec.p: Eye movements were analyzed using a combination of the Pupil Labs software and a custom-written Python script, similar to the procedure in Ghiani, Mann, and Brenner (2024). Blinks and fixations were automatically detected by the Pupil Labs software. Blinks were removed from the data. We adopted the saccade detection algorithm used in Ghiani et al. (2024). The gaze data were first smoothed by fitting a second-order polynomial (Savitzky–Golay) to the data using least squares regression within a window of 0.02 seconds. This allowed us to calculate the velocity and acceleration of the eyes at each moment. Velocity was computed by taking the first-order derivative of the polynomial fits to the horizontal and vertical gaze data, squaring these derivatives, and summing them. Acceleration was similarly computed by taking the second-order derivative of the polynomial fits, squaring these derivatives, and summing them. We then ranked these velocity and acceleration values and computed probabilities for each. The ranks were transformed into probabilities using a power function where ranks were raised to the power of 6.58. This transformation was designed such that only the top 10% of the ranked velocities and accelerations have a probability greater than 0.5. To identify saccades, we thresholded these probabilities: Values above 0.5 indicated potential saccades. We refined this identification by ensuring the orientation of the saccade was consistent in a straight line. To achieve this, we calculated the overall direction vector of the saccade by determining its horizontal and vertical components. We then computed the dot product between the segment vectors within the saccade and the overall direction vector. Any segment that deviated from the overall direction vector, as indicated by a negative dot product, was excluded from being classified as part of a saccade. Additionally, we ensured that consecutive saccades were separated by at least 50 ms. If two saccades were closer together, they were combined into one if the angular separation between their directions was less than 150 degrees, unless they were in the same direction (within 45 degrees); in this case, the smaller of the two saccades was discarded. This approach prioritizes larger saccades to capture meaningful eye movements while minimizing oversegmentation from noise, microsaccades, nystagmus, or small corrective shifts. Finally, we required that the amplitude of the overall change in eye orientation during a saccade was at least 1 degree. Saccades that did not meet this criterion were discarded.

We used this customized saccade detection algorithm because a simpler threshold algorithm based on velocity and/or acceleration is very sensitive to noise, especially in the presence of ocular conditions such as nystagmus (see Figure 1). A low threshold might identify nystagmus eye movements as saccades, while a high threshold could lead to missed saccades (Dai, Cham, & Abel, 2021). In our analysis, we used adaptive thresholds by ranking velocity and acceleration values. In our analysis, we used an additional directional consistency check, which ensures that detected saccades follow a single trajectory rather than reversing direction, as occurs in nystagmus. The analysis was conducted using Python Version 3.9.7.

sec.title: Measures of sport performance
sec.p: Participants with impairment in our cohort were international competitors in the sports of Para track athletics (n = 11, 4 females) or Para swimming (n = 27, 9 females). We extracted the participants’ best track, field, or swimming performance from the IPC's Sport Data Management System that were recorded at an international competition within the year before or after the eye-tracking data were collected. We normalized these times against the established world record benchmarks for the sport, event distance, sport class, and gender (e.g., the existing world record for Para Swimming Women's B3 in 100-m freestyle was 57.84 s).

sec.title: Statistical analyses
sec.p: Participants with more than 20% of the dependent variables missing were excluded from the data analysis (n = 4). To reduce the dimensionality of the data and to identify distinct aspects of visual function from the eye movement variables, a principal component analysis (PCA) was conducted. The data were log-transformed to reduce variance and standardized to have a mean of zero and a standard deviation of 1. The PCA was performed to obtain the principal components; the explained variance ratio was calculated, and a scree plot was generated to determine the number of components to retain.

We ran k-means clustering to identify potential subgroups among participants. K-means clustering was performed on the loadings obtained via the PCA. The optimal number of clusters was determined using the elbow method, which assessed the within-cluster sum of squares (WCSS) for different numbers of clusters. We then initialized the k-means algorithm with the number of clusters determined using the elbow method. The quality of the clustering was expressed by the silhouette score. We created cluster profiles by calculating and comparing per cluster the averages of the eye movement variables that had an absolute loading of 0.25 or higher on one of the principal components.

To assess the normality and homogeneity of variance assumptions, Shapiro–Wilk's test and Levene's test, respectively, were conducted on the eye movement variables. For the variables that met the assumptions, an analysis of variance was performed using the eye movement variables as the dependent variables and cluster labels as the independent variable. Post hoc pairwise comparisons were performed using Tukey's honestly significant difference test. For those variables that did not meet the assumptions, a Kruskal–Wallis test with pairwise comparisons was performed. Bonferroni correction was applied to adjust the p values for multiple comparisons.

A forward stepwise regression model was employed to investigate the relationship between the visual acuity, the eye movement variables identified in the previous analytical steps, and the normalized sport performance values. The regression model began with visual acuity as the predictor of normalized sport performance and subsequently added one eye-tracking variable at a time based on improvements in the R-squared values and statistical significance (alpha = 0.05). This iterative approach continued until no additional predictors improved the model's fit. The initial and final models’ performance were evaluated using the mean squared error and R-squared values and compared to assess if eye tracking can improve on what variance in performance is explained by visual acuity alone.
The significance level for all tests was set at 5%. The statistical analyses were performed using a custom written Python script (Version 3.9.7).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: We excluded eight participants from the data analysis for several reasons. Three athletes, initially listed as B2, were classified as B1 (VA > 2.6 logMAR) a few days after testing and therefore did not meet our original inclusion criteria and were excluded. For an additional two athletes, the testing was too difficult to complete because the stimuli were too small to perceive (Participant 34: morning glory syndrome; VA best eye: 1.8 logMAR; Participant 44: Stargardt disease; VA best eye: 2.1 logMAR). Two participants (Participant 2: aphakia, corneal opacity; VA best eye: 1.7 logMAR; Participant 37: high myopia; VA best eye: 0.9 logMAR) were excluded because their spectacles were too thick for the eye tracker to obtain reliable results, and performing the tests without the spectacles was not possible for these individuals. Finally, we experienced an unnoticed recording error for one of the athletes, and therefore, there were no data available. The remaining participants were able to perform all tests in the battery, despite some very high degrees of vision impairment (up to 2.2 logMAR; see Supplementary Table S1). The remaining sample, therefore, included 38 athletes (age = 24.5 ± 6.7 years, n = 12 females) with vision impairment and 10 control participants. The sample of participants included individuals with various causes of vision impairment, such as Stargardt disease, retinitis pigmentosa, high myopia, optic atrophy, congenital cataract, and Leber hereditary optic neuropathy, among others.

sec.title: Principal component analysis
sec.p:
PCA was used to reduce the dimensionality of the data and to identify distinct aspects of visual function from the eye movement variables. Using the elbow method and a scree plot, we identified four principal components that collectively explained approximately 58% of the variance in the eye movement data (Figure 2). We labeled these components based on the variables with high loading on that component (≥ 0.25 or ≤ –0.25). PC1.
Scanning during free viewing: This component was primarily defined by negative loadings for scan path during video free viewing (–0.26), scan path during photo free viewing (–0.25), and average peak velocity during photo free viewing (–0.25). The negative loadings indicate that longer scan paths and higher peak velocities are associated with lower scores on this component.PC2.
Fixation characteristics (duration and stability): The highest contributions came from average fixation duration during visual search (0.34), number of intrusive saccades during the fixation stability test (0.33), and fixation stability (BCEA) (0.30). Other contributing variables included average peak velocity during visual search (0.29), average number of saccades during the saccades test (0.27), and average fixation duration during photo free viewing (0.26). The positive loadings suggest that participants with higher values in these variables, including longer fixation durations and poorer fixation stability (more intrusive saccades), scored higher on this component.PC3.
Saccade characteristics (duration and amplitude): The highest contributing variable was the average saccade duration during photo free viewing (0.28), followed by average saccade amplitude during visual search (0.27), average saccade duration during the saccades test (0.26), and average saccade duration during video free viewing (0.25). These variables reflect the temporal and spatial properties of saccades during those tasks where saccades were required (i.e., excluding the fixation stability and smooth pursuit tests). All contributing variables had positive loadings, suggesting that participants with longer saccade durations and larger amplitudes across these tasks scored higher on this component.PC4.
Visual search rate: The highest loading variable was the average number of fixations per second during visual search (0.40), followed by the average fixation duration during video free viewing (0.33) and the average scan path during visual search (0.30). Additional contributions included the average number of saccades during visual search (0.25). Interestingly, two variables—average saccade amplitude during the saccades test (–0.31) and the average number of saccades during the smooth pursuit test (–0.30)—had negative loadings. This suggests that participants who had higher fixation rates and greater scan paths during visual search were also likely to show shorter saccades during saccade testing and fewer corrective saccades during smooth pursuit.

sec.title: Clustering
sec.p: A k-means clustering algorithm grouped the participants into three clusters based on the participant loadings on each of the four principal components. We determined that three clusters was optimal based on the WCSS elbow plot, which gave a silhouette score of 0.42 (1.0 is perfect clustering; Figure 3). Arguably, four clusters would also have been reasonable, but the fourth cluster would have consisted of a single outlier, Participant 6, who made only few eye movements during most tests (Figure 3). Removing Participant 6 from the data did not change the results and was thus retained in the three-cluster solution.

sec.p: Table 2 shows the likelihood of cluster membership based on the type of impairment (healthy vision, central vision loss, peripheral vision loss, or combined central and peripheral vision loss). The type of impairment was manually classified by two independent raters. The raters initially agreed on 76% of the cases, and the resulting Cohen's kappa was 0.61, with consensus on all cases after discussion—especially discussions regarding peripheral versus combined vision loss.

sec.title: Cluster 1: Healthy (central) vision
sec.p: The first cluster consisted of all the healthy controls (n = 10) in addition to four participants with impairment (Table 2). Those four participants, Participants 13, 18, 20, and 21, had intact or relatively good central vision but severely restricted peripheral vision and were four of the five individuals with severely restricted peripheral vision in our cohort (Table 2). Participants 13 and 21 were diagnosed with retinitis pigmentosa resulting in a visual field restricted to 5 degrees and 22 degrees, respectively, in the best eye. Participant 18 had high myopia with peripheral chorioretinal pigmentation, and Participant 20 had neonatal occipital infarction; both their visual fields were restricted to 15 degrees in the best eye. Despite their severe peripheral vision loss, these participants had relatively good central visual acuity, which may have contributed to their clustering with the healthy controls.

sec.title: Cluster 2: Combined central and peripheral field loss
sec.p: Participants in Cluster 2 were more likely to have a combination of central and peripheral vision loss (n = 14/17; Supplementary Table S1; Table 2). This was not always the case, though, with one case of peripheral vision loss (n = 1/17) and two cases of central vision loss (n = 2/17; Table 2). Nine participants in this cluster had mild impairment (sport class B3), while the remaining eight participants had moderate vision impairment (sport class B2). Most of this cluster included individuals with diagnoses that affected the retina (n = 14), such as retinitis pigmentosa, retinal dystrophy, retinopathy of prematurity, and retinal detachment: These conditions are known to cause progressive loss of peripheral vision, which may also affect central vision, as it did for this group. The other conditions in this cluster included achromatopsia (n = 1), foveal hypoplasia (n = 1), and optic atrophy (n = 1). Notably, 10 (67%) participants in this cluster had nystagmus. The average visual acuity in this cluster was 1.3 ± 0.4 logMAR in the best eye, and 1.8 ± 0.9 logMAR in the worse eye, while visual field restrictions ranged from 2 to 60 degrees diameter (Supplementary Table S1).

sec.title: Cluster 3: Central vision loss
sec.p: Participants in this cluster were more likely to have central vision loss (n = 12/17), resulting in more significant levels of acuity loss (Supplementary Table S1; Table 2). This was not always the case, though, with some cases of combined central and peripheral vision loss (n = 5/17; Table 2). Eleven of 17 participants had moderate vision impairment (sport class B2), while the remaining 6 participants had mild vision impairment (sport class B3 & NE). Eight participants had ocular conditions affecting the macula, such as maculopathy (n = 1), traumatic macular degeneration (n = 1), and primarily Stargardt disease (n = 6), which leads to central vision loss. Another prominent ocular condition in this cluster was optic atrophy (n = 4), which can cause both central and peripheral vision loss, as it did for these cases. Other diagnoses in this cluster included retinitis pigmentosa (n = 1), high myopia (n = 1), Knoblauch syndrome (n = 1), bilateral retinoblastoma (n = 1), and congenital cataract (n = 1). The average visual acuity was 1.5 ± 0.4 logMAR in the best eye and 1.7 ± 0.5 logMAR in the worse eye. Five participants had a visual field size of 60 degrees diameter or worse.

sec.title: Eye movement profiles
sec.p: We next sought to characterize the differences in the eye movement profiles between the three clusters. Table 3 presents an overview of the variables that had high loadings on the principal components (loading ≥ 0.25) and compared them across the three clusters. We considered the results for the first cluster, which contained almost exclusively healthy control participants, to represent a reasonable baseline for what would be considered regular (unimpaired) eye movements. Figure 4 shows the differences in the eye movement variables across the three clusters.

sec.p: Cluster 2, representing participants with combined central and peripheral vision loss, was characterized in particular by differences in their fixation characteristics (PC2). When compared to the healthy control participants in Cluster 1, significant differences were found for Cluster 2 in all variables from the fixation characteristics component (PC2; see Table 3 for statistical comparisons). Specifically, Table 3 shows that participants in Cluster 2 produced longer fixation durations during visual search (Cluster 1 M = 0.48 s, Cluster 2 M = 1.38 s), more saccades and a larger BCEA during the test of fixation stability (Cluster 1 M = 1969.48 min/arc, Cluster 2 M = 33813.95 min/arc), a higher average peak velocity during visual search (Cluster 1 M = 216.78 deg/s, Cluster 2 M = 410.7 deg/s), more saccades during the test of saccades (Cluster 1 M = 2.18, Cluster 2 M = 3.47), and a longer average fixation duration during the free viewing of the photos (Cluster 1 M = 0.73 s, Cluster 2 M = 1.27 s) and the videos (Cluster 1 M = 0.83 s, Cluster 2 M = 3.99 s; PC4). This suggests that individuals with combined central and peripheral vision loss have less steady fixation and fixate on objects longer than others do. This might at least in part be explained by the finding that 59% of participants in Cluster 2 had nystagmus (compared to 29% in Cluster 3).

Cluster 3, representing participants with central vision loss, was characterized by a broader set of differences in their eye movements (Table 3). When compared to those in Cluster 1, participants in Cluster 3 had significant differences in at least some of the variables in all four of the principal components. When scanning during free viewing (PC1), the scan path of the participants in Cluster 3 was almost half as long as that for those in Cluster 1 when free viewing both the video (Cluster 1 M = 18.11 deg, Cluster 2 M = 9.26 deg) and photos (Cluster 1 M = 4.51 deg, Cluster 2 M = 2.57 deg), as well as a lower average peak velocity when free viewing the photos (Cluster 1 M = 301.80 deg/s, Cluster 2 M = 189.96 deg/s). For the fixation characteristics (PC2), participants in Cluster 3 had a longer average fixation duration during visual search (Cluster 1 M = 0.48 s, Cluster 2 M = 0.95 s) and more saccades and a larger BCEA during the test of fixation stability (Cluster 1 M = 1969.48 min/arc, Cluster 2 M = 16078.78 min/arc). For the saccadic characteristics (PC3), participants in Cluster 3 had prolonged saccade durations during free viewing of the photos (Cluster 1 M = 45.54 ms, Cluster 2 M = 55.98 ms) and videos (Cluster 1 M = 58.14 ms, Cluster 2 M = 70.81 ms). For visual search (PC4), the participants in Cluster 3 had significantly longer fixation durations when free viewing the videos (Cluster 1 M = 0.83 s, Cluster 2 M = 1.31 s), shorter scan path during the test of visual search (Cluster 1 M = 2.29 deg, Cluster 2 M = 0.97 deg), and smaller saccades during the test of saccades (Cluster 1 M = 4.32, Cluster 2 M = 3.19 deg). In sum, the participants in Cluster 3, who were more likely to have central vision loss only, typically used longer fixation durations, had shorter and slower scan paths, had poor fixation stability, and produced saccades that were shorter yet of longer duration and lower velocity.

sec.title: Predicting sport performance
sec.p: A forward stepwise linear regression model was employed to investigate the relationship between visual acuity, the eye movement variables, and sport performance. In the initial step, we only included visual acuity in the best and worse eye as features. This did not yield a significant regression (p > 0.05; R-squared = 0.1), suggesting no relationship between visual acuity and sport performance alone in our cohort. We then iteratively added eye movement features based on their significance to the model until adding more features did not improve the model. This resulted in a regression model with a total of six features (Figure 6). These features included the initial two features, visual acuity in the best eye and visual acuity in the worse eye, and eye movement variables: average fixation duration during photo free viewing, the number of saccades during fixation, average scan path during visual search, and average saccade duration during photo free viewing. This model was significant (p < 0.001) with an R-squared of 0.522, indicating that approximately 52.2% of the variance in sport performance could be explained by visual acuity and the selected eye movement metrics. The mean squared error was 0.004, suggesting good predictive accuracy (Figure 5).

sec.p: Among the selected features (see Figure 6), the average fixation duration during photo free viewing had the strongest positive association with normalized race time (coefficient = 0.144, p < 0.001), suggesting that longer fixation durations during this task are linked with slower race times. The average saccade duration during photo free viewing also showed a significant positive relationship (coefficient = 2.672, p < 0.05), indicating that longer saccades during free viewing are associated with decreased performance. In contrast, visual acuity in the best eye had a significant negative relationship with normalized race times (coefficient = –0.119, p < 0.05), implying that poorer visual acuity is related to slower race times. Visual acuity in the worse eye showed a significant positive association with performance (coefficient = 0.080, p < 0.05), suggesting that worse vision in the worst eye is linked to slower race times. Similarly, the number of intrusive saccades during the fixation stability task negatively impacted performance (coefficient = –0.002, p < 0.05), indicating that more intrusive saccades during fixation stability are associated with slower normalized race times. Finally, the average scan path during visual search had a significant negative effect (coefficient = –0.059, p < 0.05), with longer scan paths indicating poorer performance.

sec.p: When only including eye-tracking variables in the forward stepwise regression, we obtained a significant regression model (p < 0.05) with only two features: average fixation duration during visual search and the number of saccades during fixation stability. The R-squared was 0.23 with a mean squared error of 0.007. While this limited model indicates that eye-tracking features alone can provide valuable insights, its predictive power was substantially enhanced when combined with visual acuity metrics, as seen in the full model.

Overall, visual acuity alone could not predict sport performance but they, together with the eye-tracking variables, led to good predictions, suggesting that the addition of eye tracking to visual function testing provides a better indication of functional vision performance.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, we developed a test battery that assessed key aspects of eye movements, including fixation stability, smooth pursuit, saccades, free viewing, and visual search. We sought to evaluate the suitability of this newly developed test using eye tracking in individuals with VI. Forty-six Para athletes with VI and 10 individuals without impairment were recruited to complete the test battery. The participant sample included individuals with a range of causes of vision impairment, including Stargardt disease, retinitis pigmentosa, high myopia, optic atrophy, congenital cataracts, and cone/rod dystrophy, among others. Of the recruited participants with VI, 88% were able to complete the test battery, suggesting good feasibility. To test construct validity, principal component analysis revealed four main components, which explained about half the variance in the data. We characterized those components as scanning during free viewing (PC1), fixation characteristics (PC2), saccade characteristics (PC3), and visual search rates (PC4). Based on these components, three distinct groups were identified through k-means clustering: (a) participants with healthy (central) vision, (b) participants with combined central and peripheral vision loss, and (c) participants with central vision loss. Significant differences in eye movement patterns across these groups suggest that the assessment of eye movements provided valuable, largely objective insights into the functional consequences of VI. Finally, to test predictive validity, the variables derived from eye tracking were related to the sport performance of the participants. We found that the eye-tracking variables combined with visual acuity were effective in predicting the running and swimming performance of the athletes, while visual acuity alone could not. Therefore, the addition of results from eye tracking to visual acuity better explained an aspect of real-world behavior than what was possible when using visual acuity alone. Collectively, these results provide a promising reason to believe that eye tracking could be used more widely as a means of assessing visual capabilities in a systematic and largely objective manner.

sec.title: Feasibility of the test battery
sec.p: The first step in the evaluation of the newly developed test battery was to assess its feasibility. Out of the 43 recruited athletes with VI who met the inclusion criteria, 38 (88.4%) were able to complete the whole test battery. In a previous review of the eye-tracking literature (Nieboer et al., 2023), it was found that eye-tracking data were usable for 96.5% of 870 participants with VI across 41 studies, although there was a notable overrepresentation of conditions such as glaucoma and macular degeneration, and fewer studies included participants with less common or more severe forms of vision impairment (e.g., corneal scarring, retinopathy, or retinitis pigmentosa). Considering that the current study, which had no exclusion criteria based on ocular conditions and included a broader range of impairment severities with a minimum visual acuity of 1.0 logMAR or a visual field restricted to 40 degrees or less, the success rate of 88.4% using our test battery suggests it is a feasible tool to test many individuals with VI. Exclusions were primarily due to participants having too severely impaired vision to perform the test properly or for wearing spectacles that were too thick for the eye tracker to register the eye movements. The two excluded cases who could not see the stimuli on the screen at a 60-cm distance had an average VA of 2.0 ± 0.21 logMAR in the best eye and 2.4 ± 0.14 logMAR in the worst eye. We did, however, successfully collect data for two individuals with VA worse than 2.0 logMAR (M = 2.15 logMAR). The two excluded cases for which the glasses were too thick had a correction of +8.00 and +6.00 spherical. We expect that if our test battery is employed within these VA and optical correction boundaries (VA < 2.0 logMAR and correction < +6.00 spherical, respectively), then the success rate would indeed increase. Alternative approaches could be to replace the lenses from the eye-tracking glasses with prescription lenses or for participants to wear contact lenses if possible. Furthermore, for individuals with VA greater than 2.0 logMAR, their visual capabilities are likely to be very limited already and may therefore not require a comprehensive assessment to detect nuances in eye movements. Taken together, the calibration-free eye tracker that we used proved relatively robust across a diverse range of ocular conditions—including some very extreme cases of strabismus, nystagmus (including rotary nystagmus), corneal scarring, and cataracts—and different severities, demonstrating its feasibility for assessing visual capabilities in athletes with a wide range of ocular conditions and vision impairments.

sec.title: Construct validity
sec.p: Our analysis revealed that the test battery of eye movements has good construct validity in that it is sensitive to differences in functional impairment between athletes. We used PCA to identify components in the eye movement variables and then cluster analysis to group participants according to their performance on those variables. Encouragingly, all 10 individuals without impairment were clustered into the same group, in addition to 4 individuals with peripheral vision loss. This result provides the first evidence for construct validity. Further, participants in the two additional clusters were characterized by differences in their ocular conditions. In particular, those with combined central and peripheral vision loss (Cluster 2) had eye movement patterns distinct from those with largely central (Cluster 3) or peripheral vision loss only (within Cluster 1). These results align with our theoretical expectations, reflecting how different impairment types impact visual capabilities such as eye movements in different ways (Nieboer et al., 2023). Overall, these findings suggest that eye movement profiles can serve as valid indicators of specific types of VI, underscoring the test battery's potential utility as a largely objective tool for both classification and clinical applications.

sec.title: Predictive validity
sec.p: The predictive validity of the test battery of eye movements was good, where eye-tracking variables in combination with visual acuity had a good ability to predict the running and swimming performance of the athletes with VI. In a regression analysis using a stepwise approach, we related visual function features to the in-competition sport performance of the athletes. The initial features alone, visual acuity in each eye, did not yield a significant model of prediction (see also Fortin-Guichard et al., 2022). However, when iteratively adding variables derived from eye tracking, we obtained a significant prediction model with six features that explained over half of the variance in sport performance, providing evidence for the predictive validity of the test battery. This result suggests that eye tracking is a valuable addition to traditional assessment in understanding the impact of VI on the performance of real-world tasks, in this case, sport performance. To what degree those findings generalize to other activities of daily living remains an open question.

sec.title: Interpretation of the eye movement characteristics in relation to sport performance
sec.p: Our findings indicate that specific eye movement characteristics are significantly associated with sport performance in Para athletes, providing evidence for the relevance of eye tracking for the assessment of functional vision. While caution is required to not overgeneralize the findings, particularly given the risk of overfitting in our model, we here provide a speculative interpretation of the findings. The strong positive association between fixation duration during free viewing and slower race times could suggest that prolonged fixations reflect a less efficient visual processing strategy. Individuals who fixate longer on a single point may require more time to pick up visual information or may struggle with transitioning between relevant cues in their environment. Similarly, the positive relationship between saccade duration and slower performance may indicate that prolonged saccades during free viewing result in less efficient scanning patterns, potentially delaying the processing of critical visual information during movement. Furthermore, the association between intrusive saccades during fixation stability and poorer sport performance may reflect the role of fixation control in visually guided tasks. More intrusive saccades may reflect difficulties in maintaining stable fixation, which could lead to inefficient visual processing during sport-related activities. Similarly, the significant negative association between scan path length during visual search and performance suggests that longer search paths may reflect an inefficient or exhaustive search strategy, possibly due to visual field loss or difficulties in detecting relevant cues efficiently. These findings are consistent with the idea that eye movement characteristics provide valuable functional insights beyond traditional clinical measures. They suggest that inefficiencies in visual scanning, fixation control, and visual search strategies may contribute to an aspect of real-world performance, making eye tracking a promising tool for assessing visual function in individuals with VI. Future research should further explore these relationships across different daily activities to enhance our understanding of the role of eye movements in functional vision.

Our results offer promise for the use of eye tracking for the classification of Para athletes with VI. During classification, athletes should be placed into classes to compete against others whose impairment has a comparable level of impact on performance. Therefore, an important step in the classification process is to understand the relationship between impairment and performance in that sport (Mann & Ravensbergen, 2018). Tests have been conducted to examine the relationship between vision impairment and performance using a range of tests of visual function: visual acuity, contrast sensitivity, motion perception, depth perception, and visual field (Fortin-Guichard et al., 2022; Krabben, Ravensbergen, et al., 2021). Yet up to now, the lack of a suitable test has prevented an examination of the association between eye movements and sport performance. In this study, we used regression modeling to show that there may be a relationship between performance in sport (i.e., running and swimming) and measures of eye movements. Specifically, the features included in the predictive model reflected the scanning efficiency of the participants during free viewing and visual search, as well as the ability to maintain fixation on a target. Considering the visual demands of VI track athletics and VI swimming, this result could indicate that the efficiency to navigate the complex sporting environment is crucial for optimal performance. For example, experts in the field of VI swimming reached consensus that the ability to swim in a straight line, monitoring the position of competitors, and deciding when to initiate the turn are the components of swimming performance that are most likely affected by VI (Ravensbergen, Genee, & Mann, 2018). To achieve these components, an athlete needs to scan the swimming pool to locate and fixate both the T-shaped marker that indicates the middle and end of the lane, as well as the competitors in the other lanes. Similarly, runners benefit from visual cues to remain in their lane and adjust to competitors (Allen et al., 2020). Empirical studies in VI track athletics (Zenk et al., 2025) and VI swimming (Fortin-Guichard et al., 2022) also confirm that athletes with no remaining vision are at a performance disadvantage compared to those with residual vision, underscoring the functional importance of vision in these sports.

The ability to navigate complex sport environments might not be fully captured by traditional measures such as VA and VF. Fortin-Guichard et al. (2022) showed that among multiple tests of visual function—including, among others, contrast sensitivity, depth perception, and motion perception but not eye movements—VA was the best predictor of swimming performance. However, for the subset of athletes in our study, we show that the prediction of sport performance was superior when taking together the eye-tracking variables and VA. Taken together, with our established relationship based on eye movements, we provide the tools for the addition of a new assessment method for visual capabilities with transformative potential for the classification of athletes with VI. Future research with more participants and more sport-specific performance outcomes other than race times could further validate the relationship.

sec.title: Group-specific eye movement patterns
sec.p: In this study, we evaluate the functional consequences of different types of impairment on eye movements. Compared to healthy participants, individuals with combined central and peripheral vision loss were especially different in their fixation characteristics. For example, these individuals produced longer fixation durations during visual search. This is in line with a previous study where the number of fixations and search times during visual search increased with increasing field loss in individuals with retinitis pigmentosa (Coeckelbergh, Cornelissen, Brouwer, & Kooijman, 2002). On the contrary, individuals with central vision loss relied more on their peripheral vision. These individuals shifted their gaze less compared to healthy control participants, as evident by, for example, the smaller scan paths and fewer saccades with smaller amplitudes during visual search. This aligns with previous results in individuals with macular degeneration and amblyopia, where it was found that search performance decreased with worse visual acuity and lesion size (Chen, Otero-Millan, Kumar, Shaikh, & Ghasia, 2018; Taylor, Smith, & Crabb, 2017; Thibaut, Boucart, & Tran, 2020). The decreased search performance was associated with a reduction in the number of saccades compared to healthy controls during the search tasks (Chen et al., 2018; Taylor et al., 2017; Thibaut et al., 2020).

The participants with central vision loss in our study also used saccades during the saccade test that were smaller in amplitude compared to the healthy controls, suggesting a deficiency in their ability to make accurate and sufficiently large eye movements to new targets. These hypometric saccades have also been shown previously in individuals with Stargardt disease (Giacomelli et al., 2021). Another explanation could be that those with moderate central vision loss can use multiple (Crossland et al., 2004) or any part of the peripheral field to perceive the contents on the screen. As Participant 6 (Stargardt disease), who barely made any eye movements during testing, voluntarily verbally reported, “It does not matter where the stimuli appear, my vision is poor across my whole visual field, so I just don't move my eyes and use the parts where the stimuli land.” This adaptation has been observed before in Nieboer, Svensen, van Paridon, Van Biesen, and Mann (2025), where a tennis player with no central vision did not make any eye movements when returning a tennis serve but still managed to return almost all 40 balls (Nieboer et al., 2025). Lastly, compared to healthy control participants, both the participants with combined central and peripheral vision loss and participants with central vision loss demonstrated impaired fixation stability with an increased number of intrusive saccades. This finding is not surprising given the well-documented deficiency in individuals with central vision loss (Bellmann et al., 2004; Bethlehem et al., 2014; Crossland et al., 2004; Kumar & Chung, 2014; Macedo, Crossland, & Rubin, 2011; Tarita-Nistor et al., 2017). Our research provides a foundation for better understanding how distinct types of vision loss impact functional vision. By identifying these distinctive eye movement characteristics, our study supports the potential for using eye tracking for clinical purposes.

sec.title: Peripheral vision loss and clustering
sec.p: Perhaps surprisingly, the clustering model did not form a distinct group for individuals with only peripheral vision loss. One possible explanation is that the eye movements of these individuals may be relatively similar to those with normal vision, particularly in tasks that rely heavily on central vision (e.g., fixation stability, smooth pursuit). Because the model grouped participants based solely on their eye movement data—without knowledge of their clinical diagnosis or visual field results—this overlap suggests that intact central vision may be sufficient to maintain near-typical oculomotor behavior in some tasks. However, we did observe, on an individual level, differences in eye movements between those with peripheral vision loss and healthy controls, especially for the visual search and saccade tasks. These findings highlight that while clustering based on eye movement features offers promise, more targeted analyses may be required to fully distinguish between peripheral vision loss and normal vision in applied settings. Alternatively, with only four participants in our cohort with pure peripheral vision loss, we may have lacked sufficient data to detect subtle differences in eye movements between this group and the healthy control participants or others with VI. As we hypothesized, we would expect to find altered eye movements on, for example, the test of saccades and visual search in individuals with peripheral vision loss. A larger sample of individuals with peripheral vision loss could provide further insights and potentially reveal an additional subgroup within the cohort of individuals with VI.

sec.title: Relevance of individual tests in the battery
sec.p: Not all tests included in the test battery were as relevant as others for the assessment of visual capabilities among athletes with VI. Principal component analysis on the 40 variables derived from the five different tests of eye movements revealed four principal components, retaining 19 variables. Four of five tests appeared to be most relevant. Free viewing variables were represented in all four principal components, with the first component consisting exclusively of free viewing variables. All fixation stability variables were featured in the second principal component, while half of the saccade and visual search variables were represented in the final two components. Only 1 of the 19 variables featured in the four principal components was obtained from the test of smooth pursuit. This variable, the average number of saccades during smooth pursuit trials, did not yield any significant differences between clusters, indicating that it did not contribute much to cluster formation and, therefore, may be less critical for discriminating visual function in this population. This result is somewhat surprising given that anomalies in smooth pursuit are established as a reliable biomarker of neurological disorders (Harezlak & Kasprowski, 2018; Hunt, Mah, Reed, Engel, & Keightley, 2016; Papagiannopoulou, Chitty, Hermens, Hickie, & Lagopoulos, 2014; Tao et al., n.d.). A key limitation of our smooth pursuit task was its potential predictability. The target always moved along a fixed trajectory, starting from one of four predetermined locations and passing through the center. This design may have encouraged anticipatory strategies. Additionally, the fixed trial duration may have further facilitated prediction, potentially influencing pursuit performance. Future studies should consider incorporating more randomized trajectories, variable target timing, or a less predictable motion pattern to better isolate smooth pursuit ability. The remaining tests had greater contributions in explaining the variance in the eye movement data. By focusing on the tests that provide the most relevant measures of visual capabilities, it may be possible to streamline the assessment protocol, making it more efficient and targeted.

sec.title: Limitations and future directions
sec.p: While our study provides promising evidence for the utility of eye tracking in assessing visual capabilities among individuals with VI, a few limitations should be noted. One potential limitation is that we used an eye tracker (i.e., the Pupil Invisible), which is less accurate than a research-grade eye-tracking system. As a result, the precision of our measurements of gaze (e.g., fixation stability) may provide an underrepresentation of any actual differences between individuals or groups. Despite that, even our test of fixation stability still showed differences between clusters: The group with healthy central vision (Cluster 1) showed less fixation dispersion than the two clusters composed entirely of individuals with vision impairment (Cluster 2 and Cluster 3; both p < .001). Importantly, Cluster 2, which had the poorest fixation stability on average (i.e., significantly worse than for Cluster 3), included 10 participants with nystagmus—accounting for 67% of all nystagmus cases in our cohort. This aligns well with the known oculomotor profile of individuals with nystagmus, who typically exhibit unstable fixation and involuntary eye movements. These results help to validate our approach.

Furthermore, we applied analytical methods, such as PCA and machine learning, that are generally more reliable with larger sample sizes. With a sample of 46 athletes with VI, there is a risk of overfitting in our regression analyses, particularly given the number of predictors included. Future studies with larger data sets should aim to validate this model. While our sample size provided valuable initial insights, future studies with larger cohorts are essential to confirm these patterns, ensuring the representativeness and generalizability of these findings. Future studies could also explore the applicability of eye tracking across different sports to refine its use in performance prediction and classification.

While our study focused on core eye movement functions such as fixation stability, smooth pursuit, and saccades, other oculomotor mechanisms, such as vergence and the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR), may also play a role in sports performance. Vergence eye movements contribute to depth perception and binocular coordination, which are particularly critical for sports requiring spatial awareness, such as ball sports or combat sports (Erickson, 2021). Research suggests that conjugate and disjunctive eye movements may play a role in sport performance (Zwierko et al., 2015). Similarly, the VOR is essential for stabilizing gaze during rapid head movements, which may be crucial in dynamic sports where athletes need to track objects or opponents while in motion (Brown, Leung, Evans, Grant, & Hides, 2022). Investigating additional eye movement variables and integrating eye tracking with other assessment tools could further enhance our understanding of visual function and its relation to sport performance in athletes with VI.

Finally, it is important to note that we were unable to reliably estimate pursuit latency across all participants in the smooth pursuit paradigm. Delays in pursuit initiation can artificially lower gain estimates, making it unclear whether low gain reflects a true oculomotor deficit or simply a delayed response. Latency detection was especially challenging in our cohort due to the presence of nystagmus and other oculomotor irregularities (see Figure 1), which were not present in prior studies (e.g., Shanidze et al., 2017). The smooth pursuit findings should therefore be interpreted with this limitation in mind.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Overall, our study provides evidence supporting the feasibility and validity of eye tracking as a robust tool for assessing eye movement patterns associated with VI. The newly developed test battery of eye movements was deemed feasible, with 38 out of the 43 participants with vision impairment successfully completing the full test, despite having a wide range of ocular conditions and impairment severities. The test battery, developed to measure the functional consequences of VI, was sensitive to differences in the type of impairment supporting the construct validity of the tests. Furthermore, predictive validity was evidenced by good predictions of sport performance based on eye tracking and visual acuity features together. Future research should focus on further verifying the construct validity by determining to what degree the results for predictive validity generalize to activities of daily living. Overall, our findings suggests that eye tracking can provide a feasible and valid tool to measure the functional consequences of VI that extends beyond traditional methods and that eye-tracking variables can help predict how athletes with VI perform on sporting tasks such as running and swimming.
